name: Data Visualization and Storytelling

topics.description: This topic introduces the fundamentals of data visualization, exploring the role of visual elements in communicating data effectively. Learners will understand the principles of visual hierarchy, color theory, and typography, and how these elements contribute to creating clear and impactful visualizations.
references: Tufte, E. R. (2001). The visual display of quantitative information (2nd ed.). Graphics Press.
Heer, N., & Bostock, M. (2013). A Tour Through the Visualization Zoo. IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics, 19(6), 1071-1080.

topics.description: This topic delves into different types of visualizations, exploring their strengths and weaknesses for representing various data types and insights. Learners will learn to choose the most appropriate visualization type based on the data and the message they want to convey. Examples include bar charts, line graphs, scatterplots, heatmaps, and network graphs.
references: Cleveland, W. S. (1993). The elements of graphing data. Hobart Press.
Mackinlay, J. D. (1986). Automating the design of graphical presentations of relational information. ACM Transactions on Graphics, 5(2), 110-141.

topics.description: This topic focuses on the art of storytelling with data. Learners will understand how to structure a narrative using visualizations, crafting a compelling story that engages the audience and drives understanding. This includes techniques for identifying key insights, creating a clear narrative arc, and using visual elements to guide the viewer through the story.
references: Pinker, S. (2018). Enlightenment now: The case for reason, science, humanism, and progress. Viking.
Meyer, M. (2011). Storytelling with data: A data visualization guide for business professionals. Wiley.

topics.description: This topic explores best practices for presenting data visualizations to diverse audiences. Learners will learn to tailor their visualizations and communication style to different contexts and audiences, ensuring clear understanding and effective message delivery. This includes techniques for designing visually appealing and accessible presentations, using data to support arguments, and responding to audience questions.
references: Kosslyn, S. M. (2010). The mind's eye: How we create and use mental pictures. Springer.
Garrett, S. (2010). The elements of user interface design. New Riders.

topics.description: This topic introduces tools and techniques for creating interactive data visualizations. Learners will explore different visualization libraries and platforms, such as D3.js, Tableau, and Power BI, and learn how to create dynamic and engaging visualizations that allow users to explore data in an interactive way.
references: Bostock, M. (2011). D3.js: Data-Driven Documents. [Online presentation]. Retrieved from https://observablehq.com/@mbostock
Tableau Software. (2023). Tableau Desktop. [Software]. Retrieved from https://www.tableau.com/
Microsoft. (2023). Power BI. [Software]. Retrieved from https://powerbi.microsoft.com/

description: Focuses on effective data visualization techniques and storytelling principles. Learners will create compelling visualizations to communicate data insights and influence decisions.
aims: Design and create clear and informative data visualizations.
Tell a compelling data story using visualizations.
Choose appropriate visualization types for different data types and insights.
Present data visualizations effectively to audiences.
